column5: Iâ€™m 27F, I hear you, I feel too old for this every day. Sending love.

Excessive exercise has never been my main challenge but eating disorders will definitely make you do ridiculous things to try to lose weight. Even now, every time I park, I weigh up the pros and cons of parking far away - it takes more time but also means Iâ€™ll take more steps and burn more calories. At times Iâ€™d refuse to take my sleep medication so I wouldnâ€™t sleep much because being awake burns more calories. Iâ€™ve definitely done laps around a store just to try to get in a bit more exercise whenever possible. 

I think my perspective is probably different because of all the things Iâ€™ve learnt during my illness and in different treatment programs. I think people can be beautiful and healthy at almost any weight and I think we all put too much emphasis on it.
That seems totally contrary to the rules I have for myself - and it is! Eating disorders are not logical at all. 
They make you think ridiculous things even if you know on some level itâ€™s not true.

For example, Iâ€™ve had a panic attack about the calories in Oreos and it being different depending on if theyâ€™re in a family pack or an individual pack of four or six. I once had a nightmare that I went to the store and there were only Oreos there, of all different sizes, and none of the calorie amounts made sense!

I have great doctors, Iâ€™m really lucky in that aspect right now ğŸ˜Š

Well my diagnosis is anorexia nervosa. I guess that means my behaviors and thoughts fit into the DSM criteria. But really that means my thoughts and behaviors around food and weight interrupt my life significantly.
I think Iâ€™m biologically predisposed and I was exposed to unhealthy things when I was younger, which helped to trigger it.
And I mean unhealthy things like diet culture, saying some food is bad, being told we shouldnâ€™t eat too much dessert, being warned about the dangers of the obesity epidemic etc
I like some fast food, the problem is I have a hard time eating enough of it - itâ€™s like I get scared

I donâ€™t really have any other sensory issues but I can be a little sensitive about touch sometimes. Mostly I just love soft things ğŸ˜‚
Iâ€™m also diagnosed with depression, anxiety, borderline personality disorder, and PTSD from an event three years ago.
No, not really, but I guess it kind of feels like the best I can do right now. I struggle with motivation a lot.

Kind of yes and no. I see a dietitian and a therapist. My most recent admission was over the spring and summer and my weight has dropped since then but Iâ€™m trying to avoid it dropping super low so I can stay outpatient. However my team already feels like itâ€™s â€˜too lowâ€™ and I kind of disagree. And thanks for the advice. Some days Iâ€™m so sick of it and I want to click my fingers and have it gone. Other days I seem to cling to it like the only lifesaver at sea
Yeah I was saying that ecigs increased by 14%, relative to their use last year. Tbh in the original study they should have worded it more clearly because it allows a lot of misinterpretation.

The INCREASE is 14%. Basically it INCREASED by 14%. And the decrease is only by 2%. Itâ€™s all relative.
Say you had a room of 100 random people - 2 have cancer and in the past year, now 4 people have cancer. Thatâ€™s an increase of 100% - it doubled. Thatâ€™s really significant. 
Letâ€™s say in another room, 96 people have glasses, and next year 98 people have glasses. That is an increase of less than 2%, so thatâ€™s a really insignificant increase. 
Even though in both rooms the change between the years was â€˜2 peopleâ€™ or - â€˜2 percentâ€™, the relative difference is what matters.
